          Kenneth

                      Enclosed is my further statement regarding my

          recollections of the 1988 semi - final as promised.

          I am afraid that I have very little to say which is

          relevant to the Inquiry as you will see.

                         SOUTH YORKSHIRE POLICE OPERATIONS ROOM

                         TELEPHONE       07^2        768522    EXTENSION & B 9 - —    1 ■ 15
ARTHUR WILLIAM JACKSON


POLICE INSPECTOR


FORCE OPERATIONS ROOM




On Saturday, 15 April 1989, I was the Duty Inspector in the Force Operations
Room working from 2 pm until 10 pm.   On commencing duty I was aware that
the Major Incident Room situated just off the main Operations Room was manned
and was controlling events in relation to the football match at Hillsborough.
Chief Inspector Edmundson was in charge of the Incident Room and I had no
duties in respect of the event.


At about 1506 that day, Chief Inspector Edmundson came into the Operations
Room and instructed me to implement Operation Support in respect of crowd
problems and injuries at the football match.   I iimediately brought up on
the Cotrmand and Control system the pre-formatted message and I then asked
Chief Inspector Edmundson if the implementation had been authorised by an
officer of Assistant Chief Constable rank as instructions require. Whilst
completing the format details I heard Chief Inspector Edmundson query with
ground control who replied that the ACC (Operations) was present and had
authorised it.   Again, whilst completing the format, I queried the rendezvous
point but was unable to clarify it at that stage.   Once completed I
despatched the Operation Support message forcewide at 1510 hours giving it
an 'E' emergency coding which means that the message generates a visual and
audible warning at receiving sub-divisons indicating the presence of an
incoming priority message.


At 1513 hours I ascertained that the rendezvous point was to be the police
room at the ground and despatched another priority message giving that
information.

lie comments that pen i4 was almost full at 3.00 p.m.   How di d he get
this information?   ls: he in fact saying that there was effe ctively

Incident       10:                         TYPING SERVICE DOCUMENT

                                                        OFFICERS REPORT NUMBER    R412

                                                                                 Staticn

Surname              RODGERS

F orenames           RONALD    STIRLING   GIBSON

0 c cu pa t io n     POL PC2697

           I am a Police Constable in the South Yorkshire Police currently

           serving in the Traffic Operations West, Main Street, Rotherham.

           At -12.30pm (1230) Monday,     17th April,   1989 (170489)   I was on duty

           when I went to the secure cabinet which is situated in the Road

           Traffic office and took possession of a number of video tapes.            These

           included number 25 which is a 130 minute VHS tape and number A5 which

           is a 30 minute VHS tape.

           At 12,46pm <1246} that same day/date I commenced p4trol in company

           with PC 2490 Holden who was the driver of the unmarked Jaguar patrol

           car, registered number F310 E W F .     This vehicle is equipped with a

           Panasonic camera, a colour television monitor screen and a VHS video

           tape recorder which is housed in the boot of the Jaguar.           The system

           is interfaced with Vascar and displayed on the monitor screen is the

           current time, day/date, year and speed of the car.

           At 1.16pm <1316)     I inserted the VHS tape number 25 into the VHS

           recorder when we were on the A62S road at Crowden, Derbyshire and

           commenced to record the nearside grass verge.         At 1.22pm <1322)    I

           observed a number of empty beer cans which had been thrown onto the

           grass verge.
I   ,                                                        PAGE
^                                  c;                                R412

At 1.24pm (1324)    I attended at the big lay-by situated at Woodhead

where I operated the camera to show the debris strewn abo,,ut»      At the

rear of the public telephone box PC 2490 Holden pulled out a number of

plastic carrier bags which on examination were found to contain empty

beer cans avid a number of empty spirit bottles,      PC Holden and I then

climbed over a small embankment which leads down into a gu11e y .         In

this gulley I saw a large number of empty beer and lager cans, empty

bottles of wine and spirits.     I assisted PC Holden to collect these

in the plastic carrier bags, which were then placed onto the road

surface.   1 returned to the car and operated the camera and saw PC

Holden obtain a document from within one of the carrier bags.         I can

identify this document to the Court if required.       PC Holden and I

then made certain enquiries at the caravan cafe situated on the lay-

by and there I spoke to a                     of                    Dunford

Bridge, South Yorkshire,    the owner of the caravan cafe,

stated that he was on the site on Saturday, 15 April,      1989 (150489).

The entire 1ay— by smelt strongly of stale alcohol and urine.        At

2.15pm <1415) in a lay-by 1 found a plastic carrier bag dumped in a

field behind the lay-by and on examination it was found to contain

empty beer and lager cans.     These cans as were the cans at the

Woodhead lay-by were in good repair and appeared new.        At 2.21 pm

(■1421) and 2.24pm (1424)   in two other lay-bys I operated the camera

to record the empty beer cans strewn about.        At 2.26pm (1426) at the

front of The Dog and Partridge Public House I recorded that the waste

bin was full of empty beer and lager cans along with other debris.

At 2.31 pm (1431)   1 recordeci, that the waste bin situated outside the

Moor Cafe contained an amount of empty beer and lager cans which were

in a good condition.     We then turned right at the crossroads onto the

A616 where in a lay-by I saw a small amount of empty beer cans, one

of which had been thrown into a branch of a tree.
 1/ 1                                                     ■              PAGE
 ?                                                        R412

We continued along the A616, the S5toc.ksbrj.dge by-pass and recorded a

number of heer cans strewn about on the grass verge of the first lay­

by.     At 2.55pm (1453)   in the next lay-by there was a plastic carrier

bag containing empty beer cans.

AT 3.01pm (1501) 1 recorded on video a number of beer cans and an

empty beer bottle (Newcastle Brown) on the grass verge of the lay­

by.     PC Holden and I then continued our journey onto the A6T where in

a lay-by I saw some empty cardboard boxes containing empty beer cans.

There was also a number of empty beer carts which were in a good

condition strewn about on the grass and bushes.       Further along the A61

I recorded a plastic carrier bag which had been stuffed behind a

street light and this bag contained a number of empty beer cans.

At 3.28pm (1328) on Peni stone Road next to the Hill foot Steelworks

car park I saw a large amount of empty beer cans strewn about near to

the pavement.     At 3.34pm (1334) I attended at the Claywheels Lane

Road Traffic Office where I liaised with Chief Inspector Lax.

At 3.50pm (1550) PC Holden and I resumed patrol and made a visual

check of the lay-bys and verge of the A57 to the Lady Bower

Reservoir.    There was no debris of note and this route was not

recorded on video.

At 5.00pm the same day and date at a bus lay-by on the A61 at

Tanke rs 1ey which is just prior to the Pil'iey turn off X went to a bus

shelter and there 1' saw a black plastic bin bag which had been left

at the right side of the bus shelter.      I made a serach of this bin

bag and found that it contained empty beer cans and other plastic

carrier bags also containing empty beer cans.       I also saw in this

plastic bag a number of white tickets.      On examination of these

tickets, serial numbers 6372, 6373, 6374, 6375 and 63S3.         These

tickets were stamped OUTWARD with a pick up point Woodside Hotel and

destination Sheffield.      These tickets were stamped in relation to the
 |   ’                                                           PAGfc.
 f                                                  . R 4 ;1 2

relevant, regulatin re alcohol.     I took possession o'f these 'tickets,

returned with the bin bag which I placed on the pavement near to the

Police car and at 5■04pm (1704) I inserted virgin tape number A3 into

the V . T . R . and operated the camera as PC 2490 Holden displayed the

contents.    I had explained to PC Holden and showed him the coach

tickets.    During the video recording I called PC Holden back to the

Police vehicle and handed to him the tickets in question and

requested him to show where the tickets had been found.                   PC Holden

did this and shortly after he handed these back to me.                    X can identify

these tickets by means of a label signed and attached by me and can

produce them in evidence if required.

At S.43am (0843) Tuesday,     18 April,    1989 (180489) PC 2490 Holden and

I attended at the AVA Department at Ecc.lesf.ield with the original

video tapes numbers S3 and A3 and made working copies which were

numbered A6 and A7 respectively.

At 10.43am (1043) the same day/date in company with PC Holden I

attended at the conference room at the Barnsley Police Station where

the above mentioned working copies were viewed by Chief Inspector Shaw

and Inspector Brown.    The viewing concluded at 11.00am (1100).

At 1.13pm (1313) and 1.14pm (1314)        I secured the original tapes with

seal numbers 3 and 4.

At 2.19pm (1419) the same day and date at a lay-by on the A37 Snake

Pass , Derbyshire I made a serach of a black plastic bag and found

that it contained an empty Vodka bottle and a number of empty beer

cans.    At 2.38pm (1438)   in another lay-by on the A57 I made a search

of a white plastic carrier bag contai ni ng empty lager cans,                 This lay­

by is situated near to the Lady Bower reservoir.

At 3 . 15pm (1515) PC Holden and I attended at the AVA Department at

Ecclesfield where PC Holden completed a working copy of the original.

At 8.53am (0833) On Wednesday,     19 April., 1989 (190489)           I was in
          I     s                                                  PAGE
                                              ;                               R412   .

         company with Superintendent Brougham,    Inspector Cawthorn and PC

        Holden in the Chief Inspectors office at the Main Street Police

        Station Road Traffic Department when the working copies •A 6 , A7 and AS

        were viewed.

        At 1.30pm (1380) the same day in company with Inspector Cawthorn I

         handed over to DS McSloy at the Hammerton Road Police Station the

         following evidence,, original tape numbers 25, 26 and A5 and the

        working copi es , numbered A6 , A7 and AS along with the "Liverpool

         Cuddles*M Cash" Lottery Card and the tickets, aerial numbers 6372,

        6373, 6374, 6375 and 6383.      Also handed to DS McSloy was the original

         Road Traffic viewing record.

         I made a contemporaneous log of the films I made and am able to

         produce it if so required.



END OF REPORT

               On Saturday, the 15th April,               1989 C150489)        I commenced duty at 0800

               hio u rs at t h e Road T ra f f i c 0 f f ice? M a in Street, R o th e rha m .         Fro m t h e re

               I drove an unmarked van which was identified as number 4 to

               Brightside Lane Driving School where Superintendent Brougham held a

               parade and issued instructions.

               My duties for that day were the transportation of PC's to various

               point duties at the Parkway and Wicker area.                           I returned to

               Brightside Lane on stand by and then conveyed other officers to

               C omm e r e ia 1 S t re e t d u e t o traffic: co n g e s t io n .

               1 then returned to the above points,                   collected the officers and

               r&turned them to 8 rightside L.ane for me a 1 »

               As they were waiting in line for their meal I heard over a Police

               radio "Operation Support".

               As a result of this 1 attended at my vehicle and attended in convoy

               to the Hi 11sborough Foatba 11 Ground wi th the of f icers who had been on

               point duty.

               On arrival at the ground the officers went                           in and I parked the

               vehicle outside,           I returned to the ground and went                 to the stand

               where I saw that officers were assisting at the Lappings Lane end.                                  I
                                                                          PAGE
                                                                          R 4 12A

 went onto the pitch where 1 assisted in first aid to an injured man

 and went and directed an ambulance onto the pitch as it was apparent

 that he was seriously injured.           This man was conveyed off the pitch

 by ambulance.            I then assisted with the injured people that had been

 carried across the pitch to the side near to the Police Office.            A

 number of these men were dead and their friends and relatives were

 abusive and very upset.           Someone said that all the bodies which were

 all over the ground were to be carried into the gymnasium and I

 assisted with this„

 In the gymnasium I assisted handing out body bags and for one of the

 deceased,           I obtained a Priest who stated he was from Rotherham who

 said a prayer over the deceased who was unidentified.

 I returned to the ground where 1 assisted by giving first aid where

  r e q u i re d .

 Shortly after I collected the officers that I had transported and

  conveyed them to their relevant points but they were not required as

  the traffic flow was quiet.           I returned with these men to Brightside

 Lane where we were stood down.            1 transported these officers to the

 Attercl iffe Police Station and then returned to Main Street and off

  duty.

t              On Saturday,    15 April,   1989 (150489)   I was on duty working in my

               capacity of Sergeant, Traffic Operations North (Motorcycle Wing).

               My duty and direct responsibility were supervision of numerous

               motorcyclists patrolling the main routes expected to be used by the

               Liverpool supporters.

               At or about 3.10pm (1510)      I was taking my meal at SYP Driving School,

               Brightside Lane, Sheffield, when information was received that

               Operation Support had been implemented at Hillsborough Football Ground

               All motorcyclists were mobilised and instructed to standby at

               Claywheels Traffic Office.

               At 3.25pm (1525) having arrived at Claywheels Lane I was instructed

               to take seven motorcyclists and secure routes from Hillsborough to

               the Northern General Hospital.

               This would involve securing only Herries Road, Sheffield as the

               hospital is on this road and approximately 1 mile from the ground.

               The instruction came from Supt. Brougham.

               The seven officers from memory included

               PC 21 Copley ART

               PC 1796 S c o t h e m ART
                                                                             PAGE
                                                                             R395

            PC 1487 De rby shire ART

            PC 2449 Mirfin ART

            PC 1504 Cooper ART                   \          ___N______

            PC 24-59 Thomas ART

            PC 2555 Zolod ART

             I cannot recall where individual officers were stationed however

            major junctions,    roundaoubt and traffic lights were manned.

            PC 1796 Scothern and myself returned to the Penis tone Road end of the

             ground and escorted ambulances to the Northern General Hospital as

             required,,

             No problems were encountered and ambulances were allowed to travel

             without hold up.

             At 4.35pm(1635) the same date   we were instructed to stand down and

             patrol routes as per divisional order.

    END OF REPORT

*                   I am an acting Police Sergeant in the Road Traffic Division of the

                    South Yorkshire Police at present attached to the Motor Cycle Wing,

                    Claywheels Lane, Sheffield.

                    At 2.30pm(1450) on Saturday,    15 April,    1989 (150489)   I was on duty in

                    connection with the supervision of traffic flows relating to the FA

                    Cup Semi Final at Hillsborough. At that time all traffic flows were

                    normal and units under my command had been stood down for meal at the

                    Driving School, Brightside Lane.

                    At 3.10pm (1510) that date I was on duty at the Driving Scttoej' when

                    for briefing and dispersed.

                    Sheffield Wednesday Football Ground to the Royal Hallamshire

     The only other point I have is that he refers, in the fifth paragraph
     on page 2, to calling other Football Liaison Officers and I think it
     might be as well to spccify which ones, bearing in mind tha t we are
     now seeking evidence from other Forces in connection with a possible.

     would be embarrassing to us if they had such information an 3 allege
     that they did disclose .it.



     Yours sincerely,

      13.            C o n t r o l R o o m C o m m unications iOfficers

      In y o u r a b s e n c e , J s p o k e to S u p e r i n t e n d e n t B e n n e t t y e s t e r d a y t o m a k e
      t h e p o i n t t h a t t h e t h r e e O f f i c e r s a n d Mr. S a n d e r s o n h a v e si i g h t l y
      d.i 1 levrent p e r s p e c t i v e s as to e x a c t l y w h a t h a p p e n e d in r e l a t ion t o
      the c o m m u n i c a t i o n s problems.
      .

      f a c t u a l l y , t h e s t a t e m e n t s al l a g r e e that, a f t e r Mr. S a n d e r s o n 's
      v i s i t , t h e r e w a s w o r k i n g r a d i o c o m m u n i c a t i o n , b u t o n l y on t a l k -
      t h r o u g h v i a t h e h a n d - h e i d rad io .        T h e t e n o r of Mr, S a n d e r s o n 's
      s t a t e m e n t is t h a t t h i s w a s p e r f e c t l y s a t i s f a c t o r y a n d d i d n ot g i v e
      rise to any problems.                     H o w e v e r , as 1 u n d e r s t a n d it, t h e fac t t h a t
      t h e r a d i o c o u l d o n l y be o p e r a t e d on t a l k - t h r o u g h m e a n t t h a t a n y
      c o n t r o l r o o m t r a n s m i s s i o n w o u l d a u t o m a t i c a l l y b e c u t - o f f by an
      i n c o m i n g t r a n s m i s s i o n f r o m a n y of t h e O f f i c e r s w i t h a h a n d - ield
      ra dio .        A s t h e r e were: l i k e l y to be a n u m b e r of s u c h t r a n s m i s si o n s ,
      th e result, w o u l d be a p r o b l e m in y e t t i n g o u t a n y .instructions f r o m
      t h e g r o u n d c o n t r o l box.

      1 h a v e s u g g e s t e d t h a t the t h r e e Of i c e r s a n d Mr. S a n d e r s o n be s e e n
      a g a i n to g o t h r o u g h t h e i r r e c o l l e c t i o n s of t h i s c r u c i a l p e r iod, w i t h
      p a r t i c u l a r r e f e r e n c e t o e x a c t l y w h y t h e r e h a d t o be a u s e o f (a)
      h a n d - h e l d r a d i o ; (b) o n t a l k - t h r o u g h a n d a l s o w h e t h e r t h e r e was,

     in y o u r a b s c n c e , 1 s p o k e to S u p e r i n t e n d e n t B e n n e t t y o s t e r d a    to m a k e

     s t a t e m e n t is t h a t t h i s w a s p e r f e c t l y s a t i s f a c t o r y a n d d i d no t g i v e
     r i s e to a n y p r o b l e m s .         H o w e v e r , as I u n d e r s t a n d it, t h e fac t t h a t
     t h e r a d i o c o u l d o n l y be o p e r a t e d on t a l k - t h r o u g h m e a n t t h a t a n y
     c o n t r o l r o o m t r a n s m i s s i o n w o u l d a u t o m a t i c a l l y be c u t - o f f by an
     i n c o m i n g t r a n s m i s s i o n f r o m a n y of t h e O f f i c e r s w i t h a h a n d - h e l d
     radio.           As t h e r e w e r e l i k e l y to be a n u m b e r of s u c h t r a n s m i s s i o n s ,

     t h e g r o u n d c o n t r o l box.

13.2       P .S . G o d d a r d
                                                \
1 am n o t p a r t i c u l a r l y h a p p y a b o u t the c o m m e n t o n p a g e 4, at: o u t t h e
p a c k i n g of t h e t e r r a c e s ,          1 s h o u l d l i k e to o m i t this, unles s it has

s p e c i f i c changes.

6/7.

Page 3 c o u l d g ive the i m p r e s s i o n tha t Ins p e c t o r
M i l l e t t was in some w a y at fault in b e c o m i n g d e t a c h e d
f r o m his serials.     We sugg e s t e i t h e r o m i s s i o n or some
-explanation of h o w this happened.

c o m m e n t fro m m a t c h control:     is he sa y i n g that t here
w e r e no m e s s a g e s at all, or t hat t h e r e w e r e messages,
but t h e y w e r e too d i s t o r t e d to h e a r ?

7.4      Inspector Wardle          *

to the s i t u a t i o n b eing one of chaos.         The i m p r e s s i o n
c o u l d be g iven t h a t it was the P o l i c e that w e r e in
chaos, rather than the g e n e r a l situation.

7.6      Inspector Robinson

7 *7     D .I ■ M e e k

Thi s is a g r a p h i c and p e r s o n a l account, e n t i r e l y
s u i t a b l e for the p u r p o s e s of C o u n s e l to the South
Y o r k s h i r e Police.   The O f f i c e r m a y w i s h to r e v i e w it,
in g e n e r a l terms, prior to s u b m i s s i o n to the West
M i d l a n d s inquiry, but we w o u l d not s u g g e s t any
s p e c i f i c changes.

■UTHORISEDt CHIEF S U P E R I N T E N O E N T DENTON

            HILLSBOROUGH F O O T B A L L GROUND INCIDENI                 15TH A P R I L 1 9 8 9

          FOR THE ATTENTION OF          IHE D I V I S I O N A L C O M M A N D E R " B " D I V I S I O N .

YOU WILL BE A W A R E i'HAT CERT A IN O F F I C E R S OF Y O U R D I V I S I O N WHO
PERFORMED DUTIES Ai T H E HILLSBOROUGH FOOTBALL GROUND O N 1 5 T H APRIL
1 9 ^ ? H A V E P R O V I D E D W R I T T E N A C C O U N f S GIVING T H E I R PERSPECTIVES OF
E ^ P T S A S S O C I A T E D WITH THE T R A D 6 E D Y .
T H E WEST MIDLANDS POLICE I N Q U I R Y IEAn HAVE NOW REQUESTED S T A T E M E N T S
FROM SELECTED POLICE OFFICERS T O ASSIST I N IHEIR INDEPENDENT
INVESTIGATIONS I N T O THE IN C I D E N I'%A N D F O R E X P E D E N £E N C Y , I I' IS PROPOSED
TO GIVE THE INQUIRY TEAM COPIES Or THE A C C O U N T S * ALREADY SUBMITTED.
BEFORE ANY COPY OF AN OFFICERS W R I T T E N ACCOUNT IS HANDED TO THE
INQUIRY T E A M , I T IS 10 BE VETTED B Y SOLICITORS A C T I N G FOR THE CHIEF
CONSTABLE,
IT IS ACKOWLEDGED THAT THE W R I T T E N ACCOUNTS WERE MADE B Y I N D I V I D U A L
OFFICERS O N THE UNDERSTANDING T H A T T H E Y WERE REQUIRED F O R T H E CHIEF

                                                                                                            PAGE s02
CONSTABLES USE ONLY,AND IT IS THEREFORE NOT INTENDED THAI ANY
A C C O U N T W I L L B E RELEASED T O T H E INQUIRY T E A M WITHOUT THE AGREEMENT
OF THE OFFICER WHO MADE IT.
IT IS REQUESTED THAT THE OFFICERS O F Y O U R DIVISION N A M E D BELOW ARE
SEEN PERSONALLY,AND AS SOON AS POSSIBLE,BY AN OFFICER OF SUPERVISORY
RANK, AND ASKED TO AUTHORISE DISCLOSURE OF THE ACCOUNTS THEY GAVE,,
E A ^ Y CONFIRMATION OF THE OFFICERS AGREEMENTS OR OBJECTIONS TO T H E
k J B a S E O F COPIES OF THEIR ACCOUNTS IS REQUIRED* IF AT ALL. POSSIBLE,
NO LATER THAN 12 NOON 1 1 T H . M A Y 1989,AND T E L E P H O N E REPLIES S H O U L D
BE DIRECTED,IN THE FIRST I N S T A N C E TO DC1 FOSTER, HEADQUARTERS CiD,
AT EXTENSION 3 3 2 3 FOR COLLATION,
THE SOLICITORS ACTING FOR THE CHIEF CONSTABLE HAVE ALREADY
RAISED MATTERS C O N C E R N I N G CERTAIN OF THE W R I T T E N ACCOUNTS P R O V I D E D
INDIVIDUAL OFFICERS WHICH REQUIRE C L A R A F 1CAT IO N , A N D FURTHER
ARRANGEMENTS ARE 10 BE MADE TO D I S C U S S THESE MATSERS PERSONALLY
W I T H T H E OFFICERS C O N C E R N E D .

    DCC



    Message from ACC, Mr Jones (West Midlands) as follows



    "Reference to the letter from Mr Wright to Mr Dear
    requesting copy documentation, i e , videos, logs, etc.,
    that letter has been received by Mr Dear and has been
    passed to Lord Justice Taylor.

«   Lord Justice Taylor will be in the not too distant
    future X passing that to his Counsel who he is
    appointing and a decision will be made quickly and
    communicated back to Mr Wright".




    Mr Jones has tried to contact Mr Wright to inform
    him of the above without success, hence the message
    to you.  He can be contacted by telephone for the
    next five minutes only - wanted you to have the
    above message so that if you wish to query anything
    with him you can call him straight away.

    I have a telephone number if you wish to ring.

                     Division                                           ■■'be asked to provide
                     written accounts Of their duties and activities relating to the FA C
                     Semi-Final at Hillsborough on 15 April 1 9 8 9 - -

                     The written accounts, when obtained, will besubjected to the usual
                     vetting procedures carried out by solicitors acting on behalf, of the
                     Chief Constable, prior to their submission to the West Midlands Police.

                     Officers are being asked to co-operate               in providing their individual
                     written accounts, but the wishes of                  any officer who objects tc
                     disclosure will be respected.

                     It is requested that the officers’ accounts are:-

                     1.    Handwritten in clear, legible writing.

                     2.    Written on plain paper (not statement forms).


                     3-    To include full name, age and date of birth, rank and number, and
                           "'Station.

                           To be factual accounts only - expressions of feelings, opinions,
                           hearsay evidence, etc, are not required.

                           To include Serial Numbers, where applicable,                      and         details       of
                     5-
                           specific duties, times and locations.

                     IS.    To be signed at the end of each page.     Corrections, alterations,
                            etc, must be clearly marked and initialled.

                     Officers Bhould take a copy'of their written accounts which
                     retain for any future reference.

SUBJECT:                        HILLSBOROUGH INQUIRY


The West Midlands Inquiry team have now requested that officers of your
Division                                           be »Bked to Provide
written accountB of their duties and activitieB relating to the FA Cup
Semi-Final at Hillsborough on 15 April 1989-

The written accounts, when obtained, will be subjected to the u®ual
vetting procedures carried out by solicitors acting on behalf of the
Chief Constable, prior to their Buboiasion to tbe West Midlands Police.

Officers    are being      asked to co-operate in providing their individual
written     accounts,      but the wishes of any officer     who objects  to
disclosure will be respected.

It is requested that tbe officers’ accounts are:-

1.     Handwritten in clear, legible writing.

2.     Written on plain paper (not statement forms).

3.     To include full name,    age and date of birth, rank and              number,    and
       station.

*.     To   be   factual   accounts only - expressions of feelings,             opinions,
        hearsay evidence, etc, are not required.

5.     To    include   Serial    Numbers,   where   applicable,       and details         of
        specific duties, times and locations.

-6 .   To be signed at the end of each page.     Corrections, alterations,
       etc, »ust be clearly narked and initialled.

Officers should take a copy'of their written accounts which they should
 retain for any future reference.

Please supply a written account on the lines outlined above and return to
"PC GRE KN WA Y", Hillisborough Incident, War Room, H Q . , Snig Hill, Sheffield.

West Midlands have only just requested a report from you apparently hav in g
identified vour presence from other reports already in their possession.
Any problems please contact me on HQ, ext 3131 or 3129

The W e st M i d l a n d s I n q u i r y tea m h a v e now r e q u e s t e d t h a t o f f i c e ™

S e m i - F i n a l a t H i l l s b o r o u g h on 15 A p r i l 1989*

The w r i t t e n a c c o u n t s , when o b t a i n e d , w i l l b e s u b j e c t e d t o t h e ]> »ual
v e t t i n g p ro c e d u re s c a r r i e d o u t by s o l i c i t o r s a c tin g , on b e h a lf o f th e
C h i e f C o n s t a b l e , p r i o r t o t h e i r s u b m i s s i o n t o t h e W e st M id l a n d s P o l i c e .

O f f ic e r s a re b e in g ask ed t o c o -o p e r a te              in p ro v id in g        t h e i r in d iv id u a l
w r i t t e n a c c o u n ts , b u t th e w ish e s o f                any o f f i c e r         who o b j e c t s     to
d i s c l o s u r e w i l l be r e s p e c te d .

 1.      H a n d w ritte n in c l e a r , l e g i b l e w r i ti n g .

         s ta tio n .

         h e a rsa y e v id e n c e , e t c , a re n o t r e q u ir e d .

         s p e c i f i c d u t i e s , tim e s and l o c a t i o n s .

          To b e s i g n e d a t t h e e n d o f e a c h p a g e .              C o rre c tio n s, a lt e r a t io n s ,
          e t c , m u s t b e c l e a r l y m a rk e d a n d i n i t i a l l e d .

  r e t a i n f o r any f u tu r e r e f e r e n c e .

PC 3229 Price

When completing your summary could you please make sure that it is a FACTUAL account
as stated at item   k   on the form GEN 2.   There must be no CRITICISMS levelled
at anyone in the text of your summary.       There should be no mention of the word

CHAOTIC or of any of its derivitives which would give rise to the assumption that
complete control had been lost at the ground.       If you or any officer to your knowlefge
gave any assistance to members of the ambulance service then it is imperitve that
this is included in the summary. All these items come from the express wish of
DI King and if there are any problems please see D C _____ p o can assist you further.


THE SUMMARY MUST BE COMPLETED AT ALL COSTS AND SUBMITTED BY FRIDAY 9 JUNE 1989 s

                                       SOUTH YORKSHIRE POLICE
                                                                            REF:          CID/AF/JED
       FROM.                              3   1
                                                                            STATION/DEPT.: Headquarters
      TO:                                                                   DATE:

                SUBJECT:                               HILLSBOROUGH INQUIRY


                The West Midlands Inquiry team have now requested that officers of your
                Division who are named in the attached schedules be asked to provide
                written accounts of their duties and activities relating tothe FA Cup
                Semi-Final at Hillsborough on 15 April 1989.

                The written accounts, when obtained, will be subjected to the u®ual
                vetting procedures carried out by solicitors acting on be         °    e
                Chief Constable, prior to their submission to the West MidlandsPolice.

                Officers are belns asked to co-operate In providing
                written accounts, but the wishes of any of.icer                         ™c-   --b..-.,.s   -
                disclosure will be respected.

                It is requested that the officers’ accounts are:-

               ;1.    jrtWiiieiCtiiB in clear, legible writing.

                       Written on:fWi»                     (not statement forss).

                       To include full name, age and date of birth, rank and number, and
                       station.
                       To be          accounts only - expressions of feelings, opinions,
                       hearsay evidence, etc, are not required.

                       To include Serial Numbers, where applicable,                     and   details      of
               S'S-
                       specific duties, times and locations.

                       To be signed at the end of each page. Corrections, alterations,
                       etc, must be clearly marked and initialled.

                Officers should take a copy'of their written accounts which they should
                retain for any future reference.

                There is an urgent requirement for the submission of these ac®oun5 ® ^                          k
                                                                                                                ls
Pc Q&aw\riy      ^ooE^i^rc^Keadquarteis, uG aoon as pcos:


                 Submissions should not be delayed due to the unavailability of
                 individual officers through Annual Leave, Sickness, et .         P
                 arrangements will be mad* to obtain written accounts from such officers
                 as soon as it is possible to do so.

                 Thank you for your assistance in this matter.




                 D e t e j r t i ^ C hief In sp e c to r F o s te r f o r
                 C hief Superintendent Denton

                                             SOUTH YORKSHIRE POLICE
                                                                                  REF:          CID/AF/JED
                                Pc_       2-1+31           t J O J e S
         FROM:                                                                    STATION/DEPT.: Headquarters
         TO:                                                                      DATE.

                     SUBJECT:                                 HILLSBOROUGH INQUIRY


                     The West Midlands Inquiry team have now requested that officers of your
                     Division who are named in the attached schedules be asked to provide
                     written accounts of their duties and activities relating to the FA Cup
                     Semi-Final at Hillsborough on 15 April 1989*

                     The written accounts, when obtained, will be subjected to the usual
                     vetting procedures carried out by solicitors acting on behalf of the
                     Chief Constable, prior to their submission to the West Midlands Police.

                     Officers are being asked to co-operate in providing their individual
                     written accounts, but the wishes of any officer who objects to
                     disclosure will be respected.

                      It is requested that the officers’ accounts are:-

                     §$.*    Handwritten in clear, legible writing.

                     mi      Written onilti^ter'ifl^ptoW(not statement forms).

                     ^5      To include full name, age and date of birth, rank and number, and
                             station.

                     tfi     To be y i f i a i accounts only - expressions of feelings, opinions,
                             hearsay evidence, etc, are not required.

                     tf*     To include Serial Numbers, where applicable,                     and   details     of
                             specific duties, times and locations.

                     mi       To be signed at the end of each page. Corrections, alterations,
                              etc, «ust be clearly marked and initialled.

                      Officers should take a copy'of their written accounts which they should
                      retain for any future reference.

                      There is an urgent requirement for the submission of these           " “J
                      it is therefore requested that they be prepared, collated and submitted
                                                                         Hillsborough IncidentrT
                      Room, force Headquarters, as soon as possible,
                 y


                      Submissions should not te delayed due t? the unevail.biUty of
                      individual officers through Annual Leave, S ic k n e s s , etc. ^spar®.
                      arrangements will be made to obtain written accounts from such officers
                      as soon as it is possible to do so.

                      Thank you for your assistance in this matter.




                       D e t e # i \J 7 C h ie f In sp e c to r F o s te r fo r
                       C hief Superintendent Denton

On T h u r s d a y 19 O c t o b e r 1989 S u p e r i n t e n d e n t R T a y l o r , West M i d l a n d s E n q u i r y
Team, r e q u e s t e d f r o m me by t e l e p h o n e t h e i n f o r m a t i o n on t h e a t t a c h e d p a p e r
r e g a r d i n g t h e L oc a l A u t h o r i t y Emergency P l a n n i n g O f f i c e r .

The r e q u e s t e d i n f o r m a t i o n , a s n o t e d on t h e p a p e r , was o b t a i n e d fr o m C h i e f
I n s p e c t o r Edmundson, F o r c e O p e r a t i o n s Room, and h a n d e d t o I n s p e c t o r S a w e r s ,
West M i d l a n d s P o l i c e , a t t h e t i m e o f h i s v i s i t t o F o r c e H e a d q u a r t e r s on
F r i d a y 20 O c t o b e r 1989

                                                                            ACTION NUMBER A4673
       v' RESUME ;                          DC I ROSS TO LIAISE WITH S YORKS POL & OBT FROM BELOW

   . i> BY OPERATOR;                         1044                DATE;        29-05-89                 TIME j        1449

 . - ROSS TO LIAISE WITH S YORKS POL £ OBT FROM BELOW MENTIONED OFFICERS A
 B i t t e n r e c o l l e c t i o n of t h e i r i n v o l v m e n t a t h i l l s b o r o u g h o n i50489 c o n c e r n i n g
''HE EVENTS PRIOR TO & DURING THE MATCH & TO IDENTIFY THEIR RESPONSIBILITES &
POSITIONS ETC. ON RECEIPT OF THE WRITTEN RECOLLECTIONS NO DIALOGUE ABOUT ITS
CONTENTS SHOULD BE ENTERED INTO & IT SHOULD BE CLEAR NO-. INTERVIEW IS TO TAKE
P L A C E „ IF THE S YORKSHIRE OFFICER WISHES LEGAL REPRESENTATION AT THIS MEETING
THIS WILL BE ACCEPTABLE. IF ASKED WHETHER THE WRITTEN SUBMISSIONS ARE TO BE
USED FOR OTHER PURPOSES, EG CRIMINAL OR DISCIPLINE PROCEEDING, THE RESPONSE
SHOULD BE THAT THE WRITTEN RECOLLECTION WILL BE HANDED TO LORD JUSTICE TAYLOR
OR COUNSEL APPOINTED BY HIM & THAT THE WRITTEN RECOLLECTION WOULD BECOME
PUBLIC DOMAIN, IF THE S YORKSHIRE OFFICER REQUIRES A COPY OF HIS WRITTEN
RECOLLECTION HE SHOULD BE PERMITTED SUCH A COPY.

                                             S TATEMENT OF WITNESS

                  (CJ Act, 1967,s.9: M C Act, 1980,s.102: M C Rules, 1981,r.70)


STATEMENT OF                                                     NORMAN BRENT LEWIS

DATE OF BIRTH                                                      OVER 21

OCCUPATION OF WITNESS                                            POLICE CONSTABLE 2382

ADDRESS AND TELEPHONE NUMBER                                       ROAD TRAFFIC       MAIN STREET          ROTHERHAM


This statement, consisting of      3       pages each signed by me, istrueto the bestof my knowledge and beliefand Imake it
knowing that, if itistendered In evidence, Ishall be liableto prosecution ifIhave wilfullystated in itanything which Iknow
to be falseor do not believeto be true.

Dated the       l8     day of     May               19 89 .                                                        Pc 2382

                                          Signed.........
                                  Signature witnessed by      ..                                      f.vfc).......



1,                                                  of                                                              ,read
itto him beforehe signed it.
Dated the              day of                       19       .           ..................           ........... )




 I am       a Police Constable                 in the South Yorkshire Police                      stationed with the

 Rotherham Road Traffic Division.




 On Saturday, 15 April 1989. I was on duty in connection with the F.A. Semi-

 Final Football Match being played at Sheffield Wednesday's Football Ground at

 Hillsborough, between Liverpool and Nottingham Forest.




 At 1505 hours this date, I was at the Force Driving School, Brightside Lane,

 Sheffield,          when       information was             received of         ’OPERATION SUPPORT*              at Hills­

 borough.         In company with other officers I immediately attended Hillsborough

 arriving there at 1510 hours.                             I overheard someone say there was a pitch

 invasion by football supporters.




 On arrival I went immediately onto the pitch between the Penistone Road (Kop)



Signed .                                           2382
                                                         Signature witnessed
                                   S TATEMENT OF WITNESS

                 (CJ Act, 1967,s.9: M C Act, 1980,s.102: M C Rules, 1981,r.70)

                                                                                                     2
Continuation of statement of               NORMAN BRENT LEWIS




Stand     and    North   Stand     and   on   looking     towards       Lappings    Lane   Stand   I saw

numerous persons on the pitch and the crowd was spread across the full width

of the football pitch.             Together with other officers I formed a line across

the pitch in the vicinity of the half way line.                          A crowd of people were just

calmly standing around and some were sitting or lying on the ground.                               I was

unable to ascertain what had taken place and could not see the security fence

at Lepping Lane end due to the density of the crowd on the football pitch.                               I

started walking slowly towards the crowd and saw what appeared to be injured

persons being carried on wooden advertisement hoardings by other persons away

from Leppings Lane and across the pitch towards the Penistone Road end of the

ground.




About 1515 hours this date, I saw a youth lying motionless on the ground near

the goal post. I observed that his face was blue in colour, he did not appear

to be breathing and I could not feel a pulse.                         He showed no signs of life and

appeared        dead.    I   was    immediately       joined      by    several    other   persons   and

together we placed the youth on an advertisement hoarding and carried him

from the pitch to the gymnasium at the rear of the North Stand.                             On arrival

there    I was      instructed     to stay with         the    body and the        other persons,    all

civilians, immediately left the building.




At 1555 hours this date,             Dr Redgrave, pronounced Life Extinct on the male

youth.




A short time later I commenced a search of the body and his clothing for

means of identification as to his person.                        Within his personal property I


                                    2382
Signed                                        Signaturewitnessed by
                                    STATEMENT OF WITNESS

                   (CJ Act, 1967,s.9: M C Act, 1980,s.102: M C Rules, 1981,r.70)


Continuation of statement of               NORMAN BRENT LEWIS                      3




found a Lloyds Bank Visa Card with the name Joseph D MCCARTHY thereon.

Other property found on his person was placed in a property bag duly labelled

and signed by me.



At 2320 hours this date, I saw Justin SHINBOURNE, a student, who formally

identified to ae the body of Joseph Douglas McCARTHY, a fellow student, of

                             Sheffield



At 2350 hours the same date the body was then conveyed to the Medico Legal

Centre, Watery Lane, Sheffield.




S ig n e d   . .                            Signature witnessed t
                                    2382

                                   .CMNSL,,.
                                     S O U T H Y O R K S H I R E POLICE

                                                                            REF:          CID/AF/JED
      FROM:   Chief Superintendent Denton                                  STATION/OEPT.: Headquarters
     TO:      Chief Superintendent     Eroomhead        '**.               DATE:          2 June I989

                  SUBJECT:                        HTI.1.SBOROUGH I N Q U I R Y



                  The West Midlands Inquiry team have now requested that officers of your
                  Division who are named in the attached schedules be asked to provide
                  written accounts of their duties and activities relating to the FA Cup
                  Semi-Final at Hillsborough on 15 April 1989*

                  The written accounts, when obtained, will be subjected to the usual
                  vetting procedures carried out by solicitors acting on behalf of the
                  Chief Constable, prior to their submission to the West Midlands Police.

                  Officers are being asked to co-operate in providing their individual
                  written   accounts, but the wishes of any officer who objects     to
                  disclosure will be respected.

                  It is      requested that the officers’accounts are:-

                  1.      Handwritten in clear, legible         writing.

                  2.   Written on plain paper (not statement forms).

                  3.   Toinclude full name, age and date of birth, rank and                  number,    and
                        station.

                  4.      To be factual accounts only - expressions of feelings,               opinions,
                          hearsay evidence, etc, are not required.

                  5.   To    include Serial Numbers, where                 applicable,   and details     of
                        specific duties, times and locations.

                  6.      To be signed at the end of each page.     Corrections, alterations,
                          etc, must be clearly marked and initialled.

                  Officers should take a copy'of their written accounts which they should
                  retain for any future reference.

                  There is an urgent requirement for the submission of these accounts, and
                  it is therefore requested that they be prepared, collated and submitted
                  on a   ’section’ basis to Detective Inspector Gunn,Hillsborough Incident
                  Room,   Force Headquarters, as soon as possible, and no later than Friday
                  9 June 1989.

                  Submissions  should not be delayed due to the unavailability of
                  individual officers through Annual Leave, Sickness, etc.        Separate
                  arrangements will be made to obtain written accounts from such officers
                  as soon as it is possible to do so.

                  Thank you for your assistance in this matter.




                   Detepftiv^ Chief Inspector Foster for
                   Chief Superintendent Denton

        together with a list of all dog handlers - South Yorkshire Officers - on duty on 15 April
        1989.

                                SOUTH YORKSHIRE POLICE

                                                              REF:          CID/AF/JED
    FROM:   Chief Superintendent Denton                       STATION/DEPT.: Headquarters
    TO:     Chief Superintendent ^StSrk                       DATE:         2 June 1989

               SUBJECT:                    HILLSBOROUGH INQUIRY



                The West Midlands Inquiry team have now requested that officers of your
                Division who are named in the attached schedules be asked to provide
                written accounts of their duties and activities relating to the FA Cup
                Semi-Final at Hillsborough on 15 April 1989*

                The written accounts, when obtained, will be subjected to the usual
                vetting procedures carried out by solicitors acting on behalf of the
                Chief Constable, prior to their submission to the West Midlands Police.

                Officers are being asked to co-operate in providing their individual
                written accounts, but the wishes of any officer who objects to
                disclosure will be respected.

                It is requested that the officers' accounts are:-

                1.   Handwritten in clear, legible writing.

                2.   Written on plain paper (not statement forms).

                3.   To include full name, age and date of birth, rank and number, and
                     station.

                4.   To be factual accounts only - expressions of feelings, opinions,
                     hearsay evidence, etc, are not required.

                5-   To include Serial Numbers, where applicable,         and   details   of
                     specific duties, times and locations.

                6.   To be signed at the end of each page. Corrections, alterations,
                     etc, must be clearly marked and initialled.

                Officers should take a copy' of their written accounts which they should
                retain for any future reference.

                There is an urgent requirement for the submission of these accounts, and
                it is therefore requested that they be    prepared,collated and submitted
                on a 'section' basis to Detective Inspector Gunn, Hillsborough Incident
                Room, Force Headquarters, as soon as possible, and no later than Friday
                9 June 1989.

                Submissions should not be delayed due to the unavailability of
                individual officers through Annual Leave, Sickness, etc.        Separate
                arrangements will be made to obtain written accounts from such officers
                as soon as it is possible to do so.

                Thank you for your assistance in this matter.




                 DetejftiTA* Chief Inspector Foster for
                 Chief Superintendent Denton

                                          SOUTH YORKSHIRE POLICE
                                                                                                REF:                    C ID /A F /J E D
    FROM:   Chief Superintendent Denton                                                         STATION/DEPT.: H e a d q u a rte rs
    TO:     Chief Superintendent Nesbit, Ops & Traffic                                          DATE:                   2 June 1989

               SUBJECT:                                        HILLSBOROUGH INQUIRY


               The W est M id la n d s I n q u i r y team have now r e q u e s te d t h a t o f f i c e r s o f y o u r
               D i v i s i o n who a r e named i n th e a t t a c h e d s c h e d u le s be asked t o p ro v id e
               w r i t t e n acc o u n ts o f t h e i r d u t ie s and a c t i v i t i e s r e l a t i n g t o th e FA Cup
               S e m i- F in a l a t H ills b o r o u g h on 15 A p r i l 1989*

                The w r i t t e n a c c o u n ts , when o b t a in e d , w i l l be s u b je c t e d t o th e u s u a l
                v e t t i n g p ro c e d u re s c a r r i e d o u t by s o l i c i t o r s a c t in g on b e h a l f o f th e
                C h i e f C o n s ta b le , p r i o r t o t h e i r s u b m is s io n t o th e W est M id la n d s P o l i c e .

                O f f i c e r s a r e b e in g asked t o c o - o p e r a t e               i n p r o v id in g     t h e i r in d iv id u a l
                w r itte n      a c c o u n ts , but     th e    w ish es of                any o f f i c e r       who o b je c t s      to
                d is c lo s u r e w i l l be r e s p e c t e d .

                It   i s r e q u e s te d t h a t th e o f f i c e r s '       a c c o u n ts a r e : -

                1.      H a n d w r it t e n i n c l e a r ,    le g ib le     w r itin g .

                2.      W r i t t e n on p l a i n p a p e r (n o t s ta te m e n t f o r m s ) .

                3.      To in c lu d e      fu ll    name,       age   and d a te         o f b ir th ,        r a n k and    num ber, and
                        s ta tio n .

                4.       To be f a c t u a l ac co u n ts o n ly - e x p re s s io n s                    of   fe e lin g s ,    o p in io n s ,
                        h e a rs a y e v id e n c e , e t c , a re n o t r e q u i r e d .

                5.       To in c lu d e         S e r i a l Num bers,    where        a p p lic a b le ,            and       d e ta ils     of
                        s p e c i f i c d u t i e s , tim e s and l o c a t i o n s .

                6.      To be s ig n e d a t th e end o f each p a g e .             C o r r e c tio n s ,                   a lte r a tio n s ,
                        e t c , must be c l e a r l y marked and i n i t i a l l e d .

                O f f i c e r s s h o u ld ta k e a copy o f t h e i r w r i t t e n              a cco u n ts w h ich th e y s h o u ld
                r e t a i n f o r any f u t u r e r e f e r e n c e .

                T h e re i s an u r g e n t r e q u ir e m e n t f o r th e s u b m is s io n o f th e s e a c c o u n ts , and
                i t i s t h e r e f o r e r e q u e s te d t h a t th e y be p r e p a r e d , c o l l a t e d and s u b m itte d
                on a ' s e c t i o n ' b a s is t o D e t e c t iv e In s p e c t o r Gunn, H ills b o r o u g h I n c i d e n t
                Room, F o rc e H e a d q u a r te r s , as soon as p o s s ib l e , and no l a t e r th a n F r id a y
                9 June 1 9 8 9 .

                S ubm issions      s h o u ld not     be  d e la y e d  due     to    th e     u n a v a ila b ility     of
                in d iv id u a l o ffic e r s th ro u g h A n n u al L e a v e , S ic k n e s s , e t c .      S e p a ra te
                a rran g e m en ts w i l l be made t o o b t a in w r i t t e n ac co u n ts fro m such o f f i c e r s
                as soon as i t i s p o s s ib le t o do s o .

                Thank you f o r y o u r a s s is t a n c e i n               th is m a tte r.

 ♦ ♦ E N D OF MESSAGE**
+*
     FROM:                  Chief Superintendent Wain

     TO:


                          INCIDENT AT HILLSBOROUGH FOOTBALL GROUND
                            SHEFFIELD ON SATURDAY 16 APRIL 1989

     On behalf of the Chief Constable, Mr. Wright, I am gathering informat ion to
     enable the Force to present evidence to the fortheoming Committees of Inquiry.
     This exercise has no connection with the investigation into the policing of
     the F .A. cup semi-final which is being conducted by a team headed by Mr. Dear,
     Chief Const able of West Midlands .

     What I require from you is a self-written account of your actions on the 15th
     April 1989. Please note that this is not a CJA statement and it should be
     written on plain paper. It would be helpful if your account could include the
     following informat ion.


••   1.      What time did you come on duty?

     2.      To whom were you responsible?

     3.      Where were you deployed, and did     you get deviated to any other
              location?

     4.       What did you see   that is in   any way relevant to the incident ?

     5.       What did you do?

     Please begin the account with your full name in block letters, your rank and
     number and your sub-division/department. Please conclude the account with
     your signature.

     The officer handing you thisdocument will inform you howand when to return
     i t. Please return it promptly and provide as accurate anaccount as you  are
     able.


••   Please contact any of my staff if you have any queries or concerns in
     completing the account. Force Headquarters telephonists will connect you with
     someone who can help.

     Thank you for your' assistance.




     Chief Superintendent Wain
W e s t           M i d l a n d s               P o l i c e

                                                              COLMORL CIRCUS QUEENSWAY

                                                              YOUR REFERENCE
P Wright E s q . CBE
Chief Constable                                               our    ncrtn cN c£

South Yorkshire police
Police Headquarters                                           DATL               7 May 1989
SHEFFIELD




Dear Mr Wright,

LORD JUSTICE TAYLOR'S INQUIRY INTO THE HIM.SBOROUGH DISASTER

I have now been asked by Counsel appointed by Lord Justice Taylor to request
from a selected number of your officers their recollections in writing, of
what happened at Hillsborough on 15th April 1989.   The criterion for
selection is based on an examination of your operation order which identifies
those police officers who were likely to be at Leppings Lane end, both
inside and outside the ground.  Counsel are keen to obtain a
cross-section of accounts well before 15th May 1989 when the Hearings begin.

I would like to make a r r a n g e m e n t s with your liaison officer to receive as
many written submissions as possible.             There will be no need for my officers
to see yours personally, although a proof of continuity             will be neccssary
but I would hope this could be easily achieved through your liaison officer,

I am also aware that some of your officers are still off duty sick, which
might present pratical difficulties.   I would like to stress that
Counsel's request through me'is not intended to add to any distress that
some may be suffering.  Consequently, I leave it to your discretion to
manage this aspect as you sec fit.   The Police Federation will- also have
an interest and may be contemplating obtaining legal advice on an individual
or collective basis, or both.  To save time, therefore, I have taken the
liberty of copying.this letter to them for.their information.

The Invitation to submit written recollections follows the same criteria as
for the senior officers before; in that there will be no interviews, Just .
requests to which the officer will be free to decide what he or she wishes
to d o . ’ In supplying any written submission the officer will be free to
keep a copy.

I hope this is of assistance to you.   If there Is anything further you
need to know please do not hesitate to contact me.   In order to progress,
and in anticipation of your support, I have asked my Superintendent Taylor
at Furniva.1 House to contact Chief Superintendent Don Denton on the
morning of Monday 8th May 1989 to discuss arrangements.


                                                                                         COnt *u /....



THEQFrtCFfi BFAl !N6WITHTHCCO&(*h$PGNDLNCk t$
     2.



     Thanking you once again In anticipation of smooth liaison, which I
     might add has been excellent to date.



     Yours sincerely




     ASSISTANT CHIEF CONSTABLE
     (Operations - Hillsborough Inquiry)

     Copy Fax to Cha3r/Sec, S.Y.P, Federation

      In Gym

    Seating for triering
ss per plan attached       3.16 in the serial instructions) PC's in tie upper
Appendix 'T'               level of the South Stand will take up positions at the
                           internal partition gates and ensure they are open.

                           gates at either end of the stand are open.

                           Further instructions will be as directed by control
                           or passed over the public address system.

                           Officers will be nominated for individual points
                           at the start of this duty.

                                /(



Dear B

HILLSBOROUGH DISASTER - WEST MIDLANDS POLICE ENQUIRIES FOR H.M. CORONER

You will be aware that a team of West Midlands Police Officers under the
command of Assistant Chief Constable J M Jones are conducting enquiries into
aspects of the Hillsborough Disaster, not only to gather evidence for
presentation to the current Public inquiry but also to assist HM Coroner with
the subsequent Inquest into the tragic deaths. This West Midlands enquiry is
being performed at the request and with the full cooperation of our Chief
Constable.

In pursuing enquiries on behalf of HM Coroner it is imperative that every
effort is made to establish not only identification of the deceased but,
insofar as is possible, the continuity of identification of each deceased
from the point of removal from the terraces, through the resuscitation
efforts to the point of certification of death and formal identification of
the body.    This is obviously not an easy task and much reliance has to be
placed upon video film and other visual records made at the time of the
tragedy, particularly with regard to initial resuscitation efforts on and
transportation of persons from the playing area.   Police officers were very
much at the forefront of this activity and it is principally those officers
who can best assist in establishing those identification links which remain
undetermined.

The West Midlands Tepi have identified 38 South Yorkshire officers, from
statements and video^s, who might               be able to assist and you are
on£of th£se officers.  It will be necessary for you to be interviewed by West
Midlands officers and to view clips of video film and still photographs with
the object of establishing identification of injured persons and police
officers portrayed. Arrangements will be made for the South Yorkshire
                                      -   2   -




o f f i c e r s concerned to attend either at Furnival House Sheffield, the
headquarters of the West Midlands team or, in the case of outer Divisions, at
an appropriate station in the Division, and it is hoped that this will
commence on               July 1989.  It is anticipated that officers will attend
in groups of three and that each group interview could last for two hours at
the most.       You will shortly be informed of the attendance arrangements made
for yourself.

Meanwhile,    everyone    concerned, the West Midlands officers included,
recognise that further discussion of the events at the Hillsborough ground
together with sight of film depicting some of the events of the day could
cause distress to those officers closely involved in dealing with dead and
injured. Should you feel that you may experience further trauma arrangements
can be made for the attendance, at the interviews, of the Principal Welfare
Officer, Mrs Penny Grimshaw, or her deputy Mr Kevin Tobin who can offer
immediate counselling.   Alternatively, individual interviews in the presence
of the Welfare Officer can be arranged to preserve confidentiality of the
counselling service.   It may be that you do not wish the attendance of the
Welfare Officer at the time but subsequently, after interview, feel the need
for counselling and to that end I am enclosing an information sheet relating
to the Counselling Scheme together with Mrs Grimjfshaw's contact card.     In
order to maintain confidentiality prior to interviews your request for
counselling attention at the interview can be made direct to the Welfare
Office who will make the interview arrangements.  Should this be the case you
should contact the Welfare Office as soon as possible and in any case by 10am
on Monday 3 July.

It is the hope of myself and the aim of everyone concerned with these
interviews that the investigation will progress without further distress
being caused.




Yours
                                               SOUTH YORKSHIRE POLICE



                                                                               REF:            M S /D D /J W

FROM:   C h ie f S u p e rin te n d e n t, M a n a g e m e n t S e rv ic e s
                                                                               STATION/DEPT:   H Q M a n Services
TO:     Detective Sergeant Watson, Incident R o o m
                                                                               DATE:           10 July 1989




        SUBJECT:              W E S T MIDLANDS R E Q U E S T S FOR FURTHER INFORMATION


        Chief Inspector Ross has today requested the following further information:-

        (a)    Recollection please from Inspector Young, D Division, regarding his duties at
               the Royal Hallamshire Hospital. (References to completed documentation re
               casualties received if possible).

        (b)    P C Marshall, F Division, (Report N° 476) mentions working with another
               female officer in the gymnasium. C a n this other officer be identified and a
               recollection obtained.

        (c)    P C 339 O ’Shea policed the 1988 match. C a n a recollection be obtained
                regarding the policing of the tunnel, the crowding of the terraces etc, including
                any recollection of the tunnel being closed to incoming fans.

        (d)    Recollection please from P C

        (e)    Recollection from P C 2439 Bocking.




        Chief Superintendent
        M a n a g e m e n t Services
Mr P Metcalf                                                                       Your Ref:
Hammond Suddards Solicitors
Empire House                                                                       Our Ref:           MS/DD/CH
10 Piccadilly
BRADFORD                                                                           Date:              12 July 1989
BD1 3LR




Dear Peter

As you are aware we have been responding to requests from the West Midlands
team for statements or recollections from the residue of officers who were on
duty at the ground.   Largely, those recollections are insignificant in their
recounting of events away from the Leppings Lane scene and we have been
vetting those ourselves in the light of your advice on other statements.

In that interval vetting process I came across the enclosed statement by PC
3337 Thompson who was outside the Leppings Lane end and who passes comment on
the confusion, such that I feel you may wish to see the statement.          I
apologise for it being handwritten but this is the way in which West Midlands
have been accepting them for expediency.  I shall be pleased to received your
comments.

Regards




L m e r buperrntendent
for Chief Constable

    Furnival Gate
    SHEFFIELD                                                                             Date:              12 July 1989




    Dear Mr Ross

    I understand that the Treasury Solicitors have expressed some concern at the
    delay in obtaining a statement from ex~Police Sergeant Trevor Higgins
    regarding his attendance at the 1988 FA Cup Semi-Final at Hillsborough, and
    have expressed that concern to Mr Peter Metcalfe of Hammond Suddards,
    Solicitors, acting for the Chief Constable.

    I enclose two statements obtained from Mr Higgins, the first dated 2 June
    1989 and a further statement dated 8 July 1989. It will be seen that in his
    first statement his recollections were somewhat poor and he was approached
    again with a view to expanding his recollection.      The second statement
    emphasises his inability to remember detail.

    It should be remembered that Mr Higgins has business interests throughout the
    north of England to which he travels from his business base in Newcastle on
    Tyne.   Difficulty is therefore experienced when attempting to contact him.
    You may care to acquaint the Treasury Solicitors with this information.

    Yours sincerely

/



    Chief Superintendent
    for Chief Constable

    A ll   c o m m u n ic a tio n s    s h o u ld    be     addressed    to   "The     C h ie f   C o n s ta b le "

Solicitors

7/8 Campo Lane
SHEFFIELD                                          Date:       27 June 1989




Dear Peter

If indeed you are now back at work     I trust you enjoyed the good weather   in
France, not to mention the wine!

I enclose a      statement from PC 12 Taylor which you have no doubt read
previously on    behalf of Mr Woodward but which it appears you have not vetted
for the West    Midlands Team purposes.   It is a statement which was requested
some time ago   but which seems somehow to have been overlooked.

I should be obliged if you would inform me of any comment you may have on its
content.

Reqards




Don Denton

        Inspector M Sawers                                     Your Ref:
        West Midlands Police
        Hillsborough Enquiry Team                              Our Ref:    MS/DD/CH
        c/o Medico-Legal Centre
        Watery Street                                          Date:       27 September 1989
        SHEFFIELD



    ^   1




f Dear Mr Sawers
ti
$ You        raised a query yesterday concerning the implementation of                Operation
|       Support on 15 April in connection with the events at Hillsborough.

        Firstly, the requirement in the Operation Support Plan for dedicated use of
        Radio Channel No 2 was already satisfied by the sole use of the channel for
        the Hillsborough Semi-final operation.   Please see previous statements by
        Chief Inspector Edmundson and communications staff regarding radio channel
        arrangements for the day.

        The requirement to change the Command and Control status of personnel
        r e s p o n d i n g to O p e r a t i o n Support to "09" was presumably actioned by
        Sub-Divisional Controls.                That requirement is an essential part of the
        pre-formatted message relating to Operation Support which was transmitted by
        Operations Room to all Sub-Divisions.              A copy of the format is attached and
        Chief Inspector Edmundson's statement will relate to the sending of the
        message.

        Unfortunately, the "Status" facility on the Command and Control System is
        dynamic in the sense that the data base is overwritten by subsequent
        information    and it is therefore not possible to retrieve historical
        information in printed form.

        I trust that this letter will suffice to answer the query rather than the
        formal preparation of further statements on this seemingly procedural point.

        Yours sincerely




        Chief Superintendent
        Management Services




        The officer dealing with this correspondence is Ch/Supt Denton            Ext: 3435
        All communications should be addressed to "The Chief Constable"
